battles.name: Battles of Lexington and Concord
notables: Start of revolutionary war
Paul Revere's midnight ride to Concord warned the people in advance
"Shot heard round the world" was fired

battles.name: Fort Ticonderoga
notables: This location contained much needed military equipment (including cannons)
Benedict Arnold and Ethan Allen led the American forces
First rebel victory of the Revolutionary War

battles.name: Battle of Bunker Hill
notables: British casualities over 1000, Americans only 400
American General Putnam ordered: Don't fire until you see the whites of their eyes

battles.name: Battle of Long Island
notables: Severe defeat for Americans (outnumbered 2-1)
Americans evacuate Manhattan
General Washington threw his hat on the ground in anger

battles.name: Battle of Trenton
notables: On Christmas, surprise raid on British Hessians (German mercenaries)
There's a famous painting of Washington crossing the Delaware River
1000 taken prisoner, only 6 American soldiers wounded

battles.name: Battle of Saratoga
notables: First major American victory of the Revolutionary War
General Benedict Arnold ambushed General Burgoyne's slow moving convoy, stopping much British reinforcement
600 British casualties while American losses are only 150

battles.name: Siege of Rhode Island
notables: Bad weather and delays of the land troops resulted in failure
This showed that alliance with France would not speedily end the war

battles.name: Battle of Charleston
notables: The worst American defeat of the Revolutionary War
Charleston and the Americans' 5400-man garrison captured, British losses only 225

battles.name: Battle of Cowpens
notables: The battle lasted a little over one hour and was an overwhelming American victory
Stopped British offensive momentum in the South

battles.name: Battle of Yorktown
notables: Americans lay siege to Yorktown until British surrender
Last battle of the Revolutionary war

inventions.name: Lighting rod
inventions.impact: Frankin's invention protected homes from lighting strikes and inspired inquiry into electricity

inventions.name: Cotton Gin
inventions.impact: Whitney's invention offered an economic justification to maintain and expand slavery by increasing productivity

elections.name: Election of 1788-89
notables: The winner was reluctant to become president due to raging debates concerning the new government
The new president was careful to avoid any symbolic references to European monarchy
Got 100% of the vote

elections.name: Election of 1792
notables: The winner was re-elected unanimously
John Adams became vice president again

elections.name: Election of 1796
notables: Washington refused a third term, setting a two term precedent for future presidents
Only election cycle to elect a President and Vice President from opposing parties
Vice President Jefferson did not get along with the commander-and-chief

other.name: Boston Massacre
other.significance: A milestone in turning colonial sentiment against British authority

other.name: Boston Tea Party
other.significance: Culmination of a resistance movement against the Tea Act (no taxation without representation)

other.name: Publication of Thomas Paine's Common Sense
other.significance: "...there is something absurd, in supposing a continent to be perpetually governed by an island."

other.name: United States Declaration of Independance
other.significance: Announced violation of the people's rights to "life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness" justified a revolution

other.name: Treaty of Paris
other.significance: Ended the Revolutionary War and recognized American sovereignty

other.name: Northwest Ordinance
other.significance: Established formal procedures for transforming territories into states, facilitating western expansion

other.name: Constitutional Convention
other.significance: Developed a three branch government and political parties support and oppose passing the new Constitution.

other.name: Bill of Rights
other.significance: First 10 amendments to the Constitutions, listing the fundamental rights of U.S. citizens

other.name: 11th Constitutional Ammendment passed
other.significance: Makes states immune from suits from out-of-state citizens and foreigners not living within the state borders

battles.name: Battle of Lake Erie
notables: Gave the Americans control of Lake Erie for the rest of the war
The first unqualified defeat of a British naval squadron in history

battles.name: Battle of Platsburgh
notables: Ended British invasions of the northern United States
British General Prevost, the Defender of Canada, got rekt

battles.name: Battle of New Orleans
notables: Yes, this happened after the end of the war. Information travelled slowly.
Made future president General Andrew Jackson quite popular

battles.name: Battle of the Alamo
notables: Santa Anna's cruelty during the battle inspired many Texians to join the Texian Army
The site of this battle is now the most popular tourist spot in Texas
Texas essentially won its independence for the next decade

battles.name: Battle of Palo Alto
notables: The first official battle of the Mexican-American War
American General Zachary Taylor would later become president

battles.name: Battle of Monterry
notables: American General Taylor, defying conventional military wisdom, divided his army to attack the city from two sides at once
Mexican General Ampudia surrendered the city in exchange for an eight-week armistice and allowing his troops to go free

battles.name: Battle of Buena Vista
notables: This close victory carried American General Taylor to the presidency the following year
Americans were vastly outnumbered, an estimated 4,600 vs 15,000

battles.name: Battle for Mexico City
notables: Americans were outnumbered at the Mexican capital, 7,150 vs 16,000
The last battle of the Mexican-American War

inventions.name: McCormick's Mechanical Reaper
inventions.impact: Allowed farmers to harvest five times as quickly compared to using a scythe

inventions.name: Rotary Printing Press
inventions.impact: Printed images on a large number of substrates by curving image around a cylinder

inventions.name: Telegraph/Morse Code
inventions.impact: Made instant communication between distant places in the country possible

inventions.name: Steel Plow
inventions.impact: Deere's design could work soil in areas of the US that had previously been considered unsuitable for farming

inventions.name: Vulcanization
inventions.impact: Goodyear's chemical process to make rubber strong and supple to create tires

inventions.name: Minie Bullet
inventions.impact: Muzzle-loading rifles could be easily loaded and were now used in combat situations

elections.name: Election of 1800
elections.result: Democratic-Republican Jefferson defeated Democratic-Republican Burr, and Federalists Adams and Pinckney
notables: The winner was elected by vote of House of Representatives
The top two candidates both recieved the same number of electoral votes
Ushered in an Era of Jeffersonian Democracy
Jefferson had been a primary author of the Declaration of Independence

elections.name: Election of 1804
notables: Highest victory margin in a presidential election in which there were multiple major party candidates
Under the 12th amendment, electors were required to vote for both president and vice president
The losing candidate had been involved in the XYZ Affair

elections.name: Election of 1808
notables: First of only two times the incumbent Vice President would continue to serve under a new President
The winner had served as Secretary of State under Jefferson

elections.name: Election of 1812
notables: New York replaced Virginia with most electoral votes (would hold #1 spot until 1972)
The closest election up to that point for the popular vote (50.4%)
Testament to Democratic-Republican political domination, both candidates were of the same party

elections.name: Election of 1816
notables: Democratic-Republicans received the credit for the end of the War of 1812
Indiana became a state during this election cycle
Federalists had been unpopular because of the Hartford Convention

elections.name: Election of 1820
elections.result: Democratic-Republican Monroe defeated Independant J.Q. Adams
notables: The only U.S. presidential election in which a candidate ran effectively unopposed, (excluding Washington's two terms)
Continuation of single party politics, known as the Era of Good Feelings

elections.name: Election of 1824
elections.result: Democratic-Republican J.Q. Adams defeated Democratic Republicans Jackson, Crawford, and Clay
notables: The winner was son of the United States' second president
No candidate received a majority of the electoral vote, so the House of Representatives decided
Henry Clay agreed to support Adams, causing Jackson to accuse them of making a "Corrupt Bargain."

elections.name: Election of 1828
elections.result: Democratic Jackson defeated National Republican J.Q. Adams
notables: Incumbent Vice President John C. Calhoun sided with the winning candidate
The winner recieved 68.2% of Electoral votes, but only 56% of popular vote
Ushered in Era of Jacksonian Democracy

elections.name: Election of 1832
elections.result: Democratic Jackson defeated National Republican Clay, Independant Floyd, and Anti-Masonic Wirt
notables: Henry Clay had been Secretary of State under John Quincy Adams and a prominent senator
First Democratic National Convention held in Baltimore
The Anti-Masonic Party was highly opposed to Free Masons

elections.name: Election of 1836
elections.result: Democratic Van Buren defeated Whigs Harrison, White, Webster, and Independent Mangum
notables: Only time in which a Vice Presidential election was thrown into the Senate
Only race in which a major political party (the Whigs) intentionally ran several presidential candidates
Van Buren was called "The Little Magician"
Van Buren spoke Dutch

elections.name: Election of 1840
elections.result: Whig Harrison defeated Democratic Van Buren
notables: Rallying under the slogan 'Tippecanoe and Tyler, too,' the winner easily defeated the old President
Martin Van Buren had been blamed for the economic depression following Jackson's Bank War

elections.name: Election of 1844
notables: The winner ran on a platform that embraced American territorial expansionism (Manifest Destiny)
Polk was a darkhorse candidate
The winner would annex much of Mexico

elections.name: Election of 1848
notables: The winner was not clearly committed to Whig principles, but he was popular for leading the Mexican War effort
This winning candidate was the last Whig president

court.name: Marbury v. Madison
court.ruling: Established the right of the Supreme Court to overturn acts of Congress it deemed unconstitutional

court.name: McCulloch v. Maryland
court.ruling: Stopping Maryland from taxing in-state establishments of Bank of the United States, establishing federal immunities

court.name: Gibbons v. Ogden
court.ruling: Gave the federal government the right to regulate interstate commerce

other.name: Louisiana Purchase
other.significance: Doubled the country's size and opened up the possibilities for westward expansion.

other.name: Hartford Convention
other.significance: Peace-talks between New England Federalists and Britain to continue trade (there were even calls for secession).

other.name: Missouri Compromise
other.significance: Clay pushed this compromise to ban slavery north of the 36.5 degree parallel. Missouri was allowed an exception.

other.name: Erie Canal
other.significance: Gave the western states direct access to the Atlantic Ocean without using the Mississippi River

battles.name: Raid on Harper's Ferry
notables: An attempt to start an armed slave revolt and destroy the institution of slavery
Helped make further accommodation between North and South nearly impossible and thus became an important impetus of the Civil War

battles.name: First Battle of Bull Run
notables: Local residents picnicked near the battlegrounds, expecting an easy victory for the Union
This battle was expected to be the first and last of the civil war

battles.name: Battle of Shiloh
notables: Total casualties equaled over 20,000
Union General Johnston was killed in this battle

battles.name: Battle of Antietam
notables: Single bloodiest day of the Civil War, with 23,000 casualties
Union General McClellan failed to pursue the Confederate troops and was therefore replaced by General Burnside

battles.name: Battle of Gettysburg
notables: The battle involved the largest number of casualties of the entire Civil War
Between 46,000 and 51,000 soldiers from both armies were casualties in the three-day battle

battles.name: Battle of Vicksburg
notables: This location was last major Confederate stronghold on the Mississippi River.  After two failed assaults, Grant laid seige to the city
This victory cut off the states of Arkansas, Louisiana, and Texas from the rest of the Confederacy

battles.name: Siege of Petersburg
notables: After an unsuccessful asault, Union forces commanded by Lt. Gen. Grant constructed trench lines that extended over 30 mi
This location was crucial to the supply of the Confederate army and Richmond.  The union tried to cut off its railroad supply lines

battles.name: Battle of Manilla Bay
notables: First battle of the Spanish-American war
Spanish losses estimated at more than 370 troops, American casualities fewer than 10

battles.name: Battle of Santiago de Cuba
notables: Complete destruction of the Spanish fleet
End of large-scale naval operations in the Spanish-American war

battles.name: Monitor vs. Merrimack
notables: History’s first duel between ironclad warships and the beginning of a new era of naval warfare
The Confederacy struggled to source the iron plating needed for their ship, resorting to melted tools and railroad tracks

inventions.name: Cowboy Hat
inventions.impact: Stetson made this article's fabric without weaving, and can protect the wearer from the elements

inventions.name: (Hand-cranked) Machine gun
inventions.impact: Gatling had hoped that his powerful new weapon would discourage large scale battles and show the folly of war

inventions.name: (Steam-powered) Motorcycle
inventions.impact: Roper fixed a coal-fired boiler between the wheels, but he died demonstrating one of his machines

elections.name: Election of 1852
notables: California becomes a state during this election cycle
Whig party collapsed after the 1852 election
Winfield Scott was a hero from the Mexican War

elections.name: Election of 1856
elections.result: Democratic Buchanan defeated Republican Fremont and American Fillmore
notables: The Whig Party had disintegrated over the issue of slavery, and the new Republican and American Parties competed to replace them
Winner Buchanan received only about 45% of the popular vote
Buchanan is ranked one of the worst US presidents for failed efforts to keep peace between the North and South

elections.name: Election of 1860
elections.result: Republican Lincoln defeated Constitutional Union Bell and Democratics Breckinridge and Douglass
notables: Questions of states' rights and slavery fractured the formerly dominant Democratic Party into Southern and Northern factions
Lincoln was elected with support from a single southern state

elections.name: Election of 1864
notables: The 1864 election occurred during the Civil War, so none of the states loyal to the Confederate States of America participated
McClellan had been a relatively poor general who disobeyed Lincoln and trash-talked him in private
The Copperheads were Peace Democrats, staying in the Union although most of the Democratic Party had gone South
Several states allowed their citizens serving as soldiers in the field to cast ballots (a first in United States history)

elections.name: Election of 1868
notables: Texas, Mississippi, and Virginia were not yet restored to the Union and therefore could not vote in the election
The Republican campaign theme — Let us have peace — was popular in the post-war nation
Grant had been Commanding General of the US Army prior to the election

elections.name: Election of 1872
elections.result: Republican Grant defeated Democratic and Liberal Republicans Hendricks and Greeley
notables: Greeley died after the popular vote but before the Electoral College cast its vote (as did the Liberal Republican Party)
Horace Greeley had been publisher of the New York Tribune
Arkansas and Louisiana did not participate

elections.name: Election of 1876
notables: While Tilden narrowly won the popular vote, Hayes won the electoral vote by only 1 vote after much dispute
The Republicans may have agreed to end Reconstruction in return for Hayes’ election to resolve the voting dispute

elections.name: Election of 1880
notables: It is to date the smallest popular vote victory in American history: 48.27% to 48.25%
Incumbent President Rutherford Hayes did not seek re-election, keeping a promise made during the 1876 campaign
Garfield would be assassinated

elections.name: Election of 1884
notables: First Democrat elected President of the United States since before the American Civil War
This election featured excessive mudslinging and personal acrimony
Mugwumps were Republicans who supported Democratic Cleveland

elections.name: Election of 1888
notables: One of only 4 elections (1824, 1876, 1888, 2000) where the popular vote winner was defeated
Harrison won by buying votes from groups of electors called “Blocks of Five
The winner supported high tarrifs favored by businesses, while the Cleveland supported low ones favored by consumers

elections.name: Election of 1892
elections.result: Democratic Cleveland defeated Republican Harrison and Populist Weaver
notables: Cleveland became the only person in US history to be elected to a second, non-consecutive presidential term
New Populist Party championing the West, farmers, unions, and workers got 8.5% of the popular vote

elections.name: Election of 1896
notables: Bryan was the first ever to criss-cross the nation and meet voters in person
500K voters were brought by train to McKinley's home, where he would give a speech to them from his porch (the Front Porch Campaign)
McKinley would get assassinated
McKinley supported businesses and industrialists
Populist Party supported Bryan when he took on their Free Silver platform: silver as a currency raised inflation and reduced farmer debt

court.name: Dred Scott v. Sandford
court.ruling: Blacks were not considered citizens, and Congress had no right to ban slavery from U.S. territories - overriding Missouri Compromise

court.name: Plessy v. Ferguson
court.ruling: Defended the constitutionality of racial segregation (separate but equal)

other.name: Emancipation Proclamation
other.significance: The Conederacy the favor of Britain and France, and its slaves were freed, encouraging them to escape.

other.name: 13th Constitutional Ammendment passed
other.significance: Abolishes slavery, and involuntary servitude, except as punishment for a crime

other.name: 14th Constitutional Ammendment passed
other.significance: Defines citizenship, contains Clauses (such as Due Process, Equal Protection), and deals with post-Civil War issues

other.name: 15th Constitutional Ammendment passed
other.significance: Prohibits the denial of the right to vote based on race, color, or previous condition of servitude

other.name: Homestead Act
other.significance: Encouraged Western migration by providing settlers 160 acres of public land

other.name: Morril Act
other.significance: Granted states land to finance new colleges specializing in agriculture and the mechanic arts

other.name: Gospel of Wealth
other.significance: Declared that the rich should live modest lifestyles, excess wealth should be spent to enrich the community

battles.name: Battle of Cantigny
notables: First American Battle fought in WWI
Reduced a German Army salient proved the ability of the inexperienced American troops.

battles.name: Attack on Pearl Harbor
notables: All of the Americans casualities were non-combatants, because there was no state of war when the attack occurred
The US entered WWII and declared war on the Axis powers

battles.name: Atomic Bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki
notables: 129,000–246,000+ killed, mostly civilians
Japan surrendered 6 days after the bombings

battles.name: D-Day
notables: The largest seaborne invasion in history
Amphibious beach landings in non-ideal weather drove German defenders from their positions, but at a high cost

battles.name: Battle of the Bulge
notables: A major German offensive campaign through the forest of the Adrennes region to split the Allied troops in two
The terrain and improving weather conditions favoured the Allies. It was one of the largest/bloodiest battles of WWII

battles.name: Battle of Okinawa
notables: The Japanese fought against U.S. invasion of this strategic island fiercely using kamikazes and launching a ground counterattack, however, they failed
100,000 Japanese soldiers and 12,000 American soldiers were counted as casualties of this long battle

inventions.name: First Powered Flight
inventions.impact: The Wright brothers developed the first, fully functional, steerable, airplane

inventions.name: Penicillin
inventions.impact: Fleming's new antibiotics were the first medications to be effective against many bacterial infections

inventions.name: First Nuclear Reactor
inventions.impact: Allowed mass production of plutonium for nuclear weapons at the time

inventions.name: Cyclotron Atom-Smasher
inventions.impact: This is is a type of particle accelerator, currently used in particle beam cancer treatments

elections.name: Election of 1900
notables: It was a rematch of the 1896 elections
The winner died a year later, and was replaced by Theodore Roosevelt

elections.name: Election of 1904
elections.result: Republican Theodore Roosevelt defeated Democratic Parker
notables: The winner's popular vote margin was the largest recorded since 1820
The Republican Party unanimously nominated the winner during their 1904 national convention

elections.name: Election of 1908
notables: T.D. Roosevelt persuaded the Republican Party to nominate his close friend and Secretary of War to become his successor
The loser ran a vigorous campain against the winner, but suffered the worst loss in his three presidential campaigns

elections.name: Election of 1912
elections.result: Democratic Wilson defeated Progressive Roosevelt and Republican Taft
notables: After not recieving the Republican nomination, Roosevelt created the Progressive Party to run against Wilson and Taft
Taft's 8 electoral votes fewest ever for an incumbent president

elections.name: Election of 1916
notables: The winner's campaign slogan 'he kept us out of the war' was popular with Americans who wanted to avoid involvement in WWI
The Republican candidate was a Supreme Court Justice

elections.name: Election of 1920
notables: Women were allowed to vote in this election cycle
The New president died three years later and was replaced by Coolidge
The 1920 election was dominated by the aftermath of WWI and the hostile reaction to former president Wilson

elections.name: Election of 1924
elections.result: Republican Coolidge defeated Democratic Davis and Progressive LaFollette
notables: The winner was credited with a booming home economy and no visible crises abroad during his brief time as president
A split in the Democratic party divded his competition between two candidates, helping him to win the presidency

elections.name: Election of 1928
notables: The winner won a landslide victory on pledges to continue the economic boom of the Coolidge years
The loser suffered from anti-Catholic prejudice, anti-prohibitionist stance, and association with the corruption of Tammany Hall

elections.name: Election of 1932
elections.result: Democratic F.D. Roosevelt defeated Republican Hoover
notables: The winner promised reform in his policy called the New Deal
The incumbent president lost popularity due to the economic collapse and prohibition

elections.name: Election of 1936
elections.result: Democratic F.D. Roosevelt defeated Republican Landon
notables: The New Deal policies already enacted by the incumbent president were highly popular
Gallop Poll not only predicted the correct winning candidate, it also predicted The Literary Digest's mis-prediction

elections.name: Election of 1940
elections.result: Democratic F.D. Roosevelt defeated Republican Willkie
notables: The winner became the first and only President elected for a 3rd consecutive term
The winner promised there would be no foreign wars if he were reelected

elections.name: Election of 1944
elections.result: Democratic F.D. Roosevelt defeated Republican Dewey
notables: The winner became the first and only President elected for a 4th consecutive term
The winner died the next year, and was replaced by Truman

elections.name: Election of 1948
notables: Virtually every prediction indicated that the incumbent president (the winner) would be defeated by his opponent
The winner's surprise victory was the fifth consecutive win for the Democratic Party in a presidential election

court.name: Lochner v. New York
court.ruling: The Constitution bars a state from interfering with an employee’s right to contract with an employer

court.name: Schenck v. United States
court.ruling: Speech that presents a “clear and present danger” to the security of the United States violates free speech

court.name: Near v. Minnesota
court.ruling: The liberty of the pres is safeguarded from invasion by state action

court.name: Tennessee v. Scopes
court.ruling: Scopes was found guilty of violating the Butler Act, but the verdict was thrown out on a technicality

other.name: Stock Market Crash
other.significance: Started the Great Depression, worldwide GDP fell by an estimated 15% between 1929 and 1932

other.name: Marshall Plan
other.significance: An American initiave to help rebuild Western European economies after the end of WWII

other.name: Creation of NATO
other.significance: Created an intergovernmental military alliance based on the North Atlantic Treaty

other.name: 16th Constitutional Ammendment passed
other.significance: Permits Congress to levy an income tax without diving it among the states or basing it on the Census

other.name: 17th Constitutional Ammendment passed
other.significance: Establishes the direct election of United States Senators by popular vote

other.name: 18th Constitutional Ammendment passed
other.significance: Prohibited the manufacturing or sale of alcohol within the United States (repealed 1933)

other.name: 19th Constitutional Ammendment passed
other.significance: Prohibits the denial of the right to vote based on sex

other.name: 20th Constitutional Ammendment passed
other.significance: Changes the date on which the terms of the President,Vice President, Senators and Representatives end/begin

other.name: 21st Constitutional Ammendment passed
other.significance: Repeals the 18th Amendment and gives the States the power to prohibit or regulate alcohol

other.name: Pure Food and Drugs Act
other.significance: A consumer protection law requiring companies to label active ingredients and uphold purity levels

other.name: Sinking of the RMS Lusitania
other.significance: Turned public opinion against Germany, contributed to the American entry into WWI

other.name: Zimmermann Telegram
other.significance: The coded message instructed Mexico to form military alliance with Germany against the US if it entered WWI

battles.name: Action of 12 October 1950
notables: Two out of five minesweeping ships in Korean waters sank, one damaged
American survivors of the sunken ships were fired upon by enemy aircraft until they could be rescued over 4 hours later

battles.name: Battle of Chumonchin Chan
notables: The only major battle fought between surface combatants during the main phase of the Korean War
3/4 North Korean torpedo and gunboats were destroyed by an Allied flotilla before their torpedoes could be fired

battles.name: Battle of Inchon
notables: The code name for the operation was Operation Chromite
This amphibious invasion/battle resulted in a decisive victory for the UN, and led to the recapture of Seoul 2 weeks later

battles.name: Attack on the Sui-ho Dam
notables: Permanently destroyed 90% of the hydroelectric generating facilities struck and knocked out power in North Korea for 2 weeks
UN forces followed up by targeting smaller power-generating plants to prevent North Koreans from filling the void in power generation

battles.name: Bay of Pigs Invasion
notables: The invaders were badly outnumbered by Castro’s troops, and they surrendered after less than 24 hours of fighting
The failed invasion strengthened the position of Castro's leadership as well as his ties with the USSR

battles.name: Battle of Ap Bac
notables: The battle resulted in heavy casualties on South Vietnamese troops (83 dead and more than 100 wounded)
It illustrated poor performances in fighting ability/spirit of the South Vietnamese forces in compared to the Viet Cong

battles.name: Battle of la Drang
notables: Battle of Ia Drang was the first major battle between regular U.S. and People’s Army of Vietnam (PAVN) troops
Set the blueprint for tactics for both sides during the conflict

battles.name: Battle of Khe Sanh
notables: This turned out to be one of the longest and bloodiest battles of the Vietnam War
Heavy communist casualties and the U.S. had to abandon a key combat base for the first time, but both slides claimed victory

battles.name: The Tet Offensive
notables: Despite its surprise and initial success, the communists were quickly repelled within several hours or days
Shocking the U.S. government and public, it could be seen as a strategic/psychological win against the North Vietnamese

battles.name: Gurf War Air Campaign
notables: Arial bombing destroyed Iraq's Air Force, anti-aircraft, command, and communication facilities, and military targets
U.S. and British special operations forces aided the search for and destruction of Scuds in western Iraq

battles.name: Battle of Khafji
notables: First major ground engagement of the Gulf War and marked the climax of the Coalition's air campaign over Kuwait and Iraq
Saudi Arabian, Qatari, and Coalition forces successfully attempted to retake control of the city occupied by an Iraqi column

inventions.name: Voyager 1
inventions.impact: This craft takes pictures and transmits data back to NASA. It is now approximately 11.5 billion miles away from Earth

inventions.name: Saturn V
inventions.impact: This rocket remains literally the heaviest thing that has ever flown

inventions.name: 6-axis Stanford Arm
inventions.impact: Scheinman invented the first robot designed for computer control, which was later modified into an assembly line machine

inventions.name: LASER
inventions.impact: Mainman's invention has a variety of everyday applications, including CDs, DVDs, and surgery, but not as a 'death ray'

elections.name: Election of 1952
notables: Ended 20 consecutive years of Democratic control of the White House
The winner's campaign slogan, "I Like Ike," was one of the most popular in American history

elections.name: Election of 1956
notables: The 1956 election was a rematch of 1952
This was the last presidential election prior to the statehood of Alaska and Hawai

elections.name: Election of 1960
elections.result: Democratic Kennedy defeated Republican Nixon and Democratic Byrd
notables: Historians debate as to whether vote theft in selected states aided Kennedy's victory in this election
This was the first presidential election in which Alaska and Hawaii participated

elections.name: Election of 1964
notables: The winner claimed his Republican opponent from Arizona wanted to abolish the social welfare programs created in the 1930s
The losing candidate alienated most moderate Republicans by voting against the Civil Rights Act of 1964

elections.name: Election of 1968
elections.result: Republican Nixon defeated Democratic Humphrey and American Independent Wallace
notables: No third-party candidate has won an entire state's electoral votes since Wallace, who was popular in the South
It was the last election in which two opposing candidates were vice-presidents

elections.name: Election of 1972
notables: The losing candidate's platform: immediately ending the Vietnam War and guaranteed minimum incomes for the poor
The winning candidate received almost 18 million more popular votes than the losing candidate—the widest margin ever

elections.name: Election of 1976
notables: The winning candidate was the first president elected from the Deep South since Zachary Taylor in 1848
The losing candidate was saddled with a slow economy and paid a political price for his pardon of Nixon

elections.name: Election of 1980
notables: In the Congressional elections, Republicans won control of the United States Senate for the first time in 28 years
Independent candidate John B. Anderson received 5,719,437 popular votes, but no Electoral Votes

elections.name: Election of 1984
notables: The winning candidate carried 49/50 states, becoming only the second president to do so after Nixon in 1972
The Republican's campaign used "Born in the U.S.A." as a campaign song, without permission, until the song's Democratic creator insisted they stop
The winning candidate's 525 electoral votes is the highest total ever received by a presidential candidate

elections.name: Election of 1988
notables: The winning candidate became the first incumbent Vice President to win a presidential election in 152 years
False rumors about the losing candidate circulated the media, such as a mental illness, and his wife burned an a flag to protest the Vietnam War

elections.name: Election of 1992
notables: Independent candidate Perot received 19,741,065 votes, most ever for a 3rd party candidate, but no Electoral Votes
The losing candidate had alienated much of his conservative base by breaking his 1988 campaign pledge against raising taxes

elections.name: Election of 1996
notables: The winning candidate benefited from an economy which recovered from the early 1990s recession
The 73-year-old losing candidate appeared old and frail, especially when he fell off a stage during a campaign event

court.name: Brown v. Board of Education
court.ruling: In the field of public education, the doctrine of ‘separate but equal’ has no place.

court.name: Napp v. Ohio
court.ruling: Evidence that is illegally obtained by the state may not be used against a defendant in court

court.name: Baker v. Carr
court.ruling: Voting districts cannot be drawn in such a way that they violate the Equal Protection clause of the 14th Amendment

court.name: Engel v. Vitale
court.ruling: Public institutions (i.e., a school system) cannot require prayer

court.name: Gideon v. Wainwright
court.ruling: Defendants in criminal cases have an absolute right to counsel

court.name: Miranda v. Arizona
court.ruling: You have the right to remain silent

other.name: 22nd Constitutional Amendment Passed
other.significance: Set presidential term limits

other.name: Montgomery Bus Boycott
other.significance: Sparked the American Civil Rights movement

other.name: Embargo on Cuba
other.significance: Maintained sanctions on Cuba if the Cuban government refused democratization and disresepcted human rights

other.name: Watergate Scandal
other.significance: D.C. and President Nixon's administration's attempted cover-up of its involvement led to the discovery of multiple abuses of their power

other.name: 23rd Constitutional Ammendment passed
other.significance: Grants the District of Columbia electors (the number equal to the least populous state) in the Electoral College.

other.name: 24th Constitutional Ammendment passed
other.significance: Prohibits the revocation of voting rights due to the non-payment of a poll tax or any other tax

other.name: 25th Constitutional Ammendment passed
other.significance: Addresses succession to the Presidency, filling a vacancy in the office of the Vice President, and Presidential disabilities

other.name: 26th Constitutional Ammendment passed
other.significance: Prohibits the denial of the right of US citizens, eighteen years of age or older, to vote on account of age

other.name: 27th Constitutional Ammendment passed
other.significance: Delays laws affecting Congressional salary from taking effect until after the next election of representatives
